Review title: One of the great epics of all time and one of the great cinematic achievements of all time
Review_body: Ben-Hur is widely hailed as a classic film and a great epic masterpiece among movie buffs and critics.Why is it so? Because it has character, drama, action, violence, redemption, hope, color, and intelligence in it; it is one of the best (and maybe THE best) of the biblical epics of Hollywood's Golden Age.The story goes like this: In first century (A.D., that is) Judea, the Jewish prince Judah Ben-Hur (Charlton Heston) meets his former friend Messala (Stephen Boyd), who has now become a Roman tribute. At first, it seems that they will be friends again. However, when Messala demands that Judah reveal the names of militants who oppose the Roman Empire, Judah breaks with Messala, and vice versa. This event spills over when Judah is falsely accused of attempting to assassinate the Roman governor after a tile accidentally falls from the palace balcony, and he and his family are captured. Judah begs Messala to vindicate him and his family, but the hardened Roman refuses. Judah is condemned to the galleys, but not before he promises vengeance on Messala when he returns. At the galleys, he saves the life of the general Quintus Arrius (Jack Hawkins) and is rewarded by being named Arrius's son. However, Judah feels haunted by the memory of Judea, and returns, only to meet Sheik Ilderim (Hugh Griffith) and Balthasar (Finlay Currie), who happened to be one of the three wise men who saw the baby Jesus, and to enter into a chariot race in which he will compete with Messala in the arena. The ensuing events will make for an exciting, grand piece of cinema.Did the movie deserve the glowing reputation it has received among esteemed film critics and movie buffs? Or is it just an average epic that is dated and insignificant? Or is it a really awful, bloated and overrated piece of fluff? I agree with the first opinion. It is an intelligent piece of filmmaking that keeps you in your seat for more than three and a half hours, even with the occasional flaws that may exist in the movie.William Wyler does a wonderful job in directing the film, and the movie is guided by his skilled hand. Epic film producer Sam Zimbalist (King Solomon's Mines, Quo Vadis) did a great job in his production; however, he died in 1958 before it could be completed, making him the only posthumous person to win a Best Picture Oscar. Karl Tunberg's excellent script is helped with uncredited contributions from British playwright Christopher Fry, American playwrights Maxwell Anderson and S. N. Behrman, and the late great author Gore Vidal, who also happened to write Broadway plays. The fact that the uncredited contributions come from playwrights clears things up a bit as to why this film is so grand, epic, and magnificent. The script should be studied by film buffs and aspiring filmmakers as an excellent example of epic filmmaking. And not only that, Lew Wallace's classic, on which the film is based, should be read also in conjunction with the film script. Miklos Rozsa's music, Robert Surtees's cinematography and Yakima Canutt's stunts all have their share in elevating this already wonderful film.Charlton Heston plays his role as the Jewish prince with dignity, awesomeness, and humanity, even though he may have his occasions of stiltedness and woodenness. However, there is a difference from the book and the movie; whereas in the book Ben-Hur is shown to be joining a guerrilla force with the Galileans against the Roman government, and he even kills a Roman soldier in a duel, while the movie shows none of this. It does deal with Ben-Hur's hatred of the Roman government, though, and how it nearly blinds him to the need to love his enemies. Another difference is that in the book Ben-Hur is depicted to be much younger in the beginning, whereas in the movie he is a grown man. Stephen Boyd brilliantly portrays the villainous Messala, who is desirous of power, glory, and pomp. However, unlike the novel's character, Messala is not very cynical, though he is laden with hubris. The Israeli actress Haya Harareet fits well into the role of the beautiful Esther, and Hugh Griffith's portrayal as Sheik Ilderim provides us some comic relief throughout the epic tale. And Jack Hawkins's role as Arrius is compelling as well.And let us not forget the brilliant and electric chariot race. The race is constructed entirely without CGi and without any phony trickery; it is all real. The sets are huge, magnificent and epic. And it entirely relies on the suspense of the event rather than Miklos Rozsa's music (which is wonderful in its own right). It not only focuses on epic scale but rather the conflict between Ben-Hur and Messala, and in this way it contributes to the story and doesn't detract from it.The most important part of the epic, however, is the story of Christ, as the subtitle of the original book (and the movie) says it is "A Tale of the Christ." Claude Heater plays the role here. In the film, Christ's face is not shown, and yet His power infuses the whole movie both indirectly and directly, particularly in the famous scene where Jesus gives water to a thirsty Judah Ben-Hur, who is on his way to the galleys. When He faces a Roman soldier who commands that no water be given to Judah, Jesus' look has such strength that the soldier stops himself from whipping Jesus. The Christian core is shown throughout the film by contrasting the power of true love as exemplified by Christ Jesus and the hatred that Messala shows and that Judah succumbs to before his salvation. Recommended to all film buffs, epic film fans, and Christians of all backgrounds. This film is epic, human, and wonderful. I give it five out of five stars.

I have watched a lot of great movies but this one tops. From the production design to cinematography to great casts considering the year that the movie was made. You can't compare this to any movies that have the same stories because Ben-Hur is special. Probably the best movie of all time.

Review_body: I saw 'Ben Hur' when I was 15 years of age and was amazed at the wonderful structure of the film. The movie itself is basically historically and Biblically correct (even though it is a piece of fiction). However, there are a few inaccuracies here and there, which by no means take away from the grandeur of the film. First of all, the Romans had no concept of "emperor" as the word is understood today. The Roman "emperors" were imperial dictators with a variety of powers (based upon Latin words), which were bestowed upon them by the Senate. They have been labeled "emperors" because one of the titles the Senate gave was "imperator", which in Latin means, "commander-in-chief". The other inaccuracy is the very nature of Tiberius. He was far from the benevolent figure portrayed in this movie, or in "The Robe". Tiberius was a paranoid tyrant, who had members of his family murdered on suspicion of treason. As this film wrongly portrays, he was also never in Rome, but had a private villa on the island of Capri, and left most of the affairs of state to his Praetorian Prefect, Sejanus. Always suspicious, Tiberius opened what he called "treason trials" where rumored enemies of the state were tried, convicted and murdered in cruel and unusual manners.

Review title: ONE OF MY TOP TEN OF ALL TIME!!!
Review_body: If you have not seen BEN HUR, you have not lived, man.Best movie of all time.I have a list of my all-time top Christian films and this is #1.Ben Hur (Charlton Heston) is a Jewish noble who is torn between his loyalties to his people and his duty to Rome. Every time he is faced with that choice, he chooses his people, and in doing so tends to make enemies of Rome. His first enemy is Masala, a Roman diplomat in Jerusalem, and when his sister accidentally knocks a roof tile onto a Roman dignitary, he is arrested and sold as a slave. While traveling through the desert on his way to Ceserea to be put onto a slave galley he meets a man in the wilderness who gives him water.However, to cut a very long story short, he saves the captains life during a battle with pirates, and is made a freeman. He then returns to Jerusalem where he confronts Masala in the famous chariot race, and wins. However, he discovers that his family have been outcast as lepers and rages against Rome. But this rage is tempered through the teachings of Christ, and the movie concludes with him sitting at the foot of the cross watching Jesus die.Water plays a significant role in this movie. Christ gives him water in the desert which enables him to survive. His life is again saved when he is on the water after the slave master frees him from his chains. When he watches Christ go to the cross, he attempts to return the favour by giving him water, and when Christ dies, rain falls from the heavens in a ferocious storm.Ben Hur is about the rage that overwhelms us, and the freedom that Christ gives us from this rage. Ben Hur is torn by betrayal. He was betrayed by Masala when he was sold as a slave, and he was betrayed by Rome when his mother and sister where thrown into the leper colonies. He is further betrayed by Rome when he takes his mother and sister to see Christ only to find that he has been sentenced to death.

This is the Greatest Film Ever Made! I recommend you see it in true HD quality and under the latest restored version. The acting, casting, cinematography, music, stunts, story line, art, drama, etc. is all at full epic scale.Cecil B. DeMille and Charlton Heston demonstrated their command of Hollywood. Ben-Hur, a great family classic, should be passed on for generations to come. I highly recommend the film to all peoples and generations. I wish it would be shown again in IMAX someday. That would be amazing to see the chariot race in true HD at a movie theater near you! Go Ben-Hur go!

Obviously most viewers do not know the book. Judah Ben Hur was 15 when the tile slipped from under HIS hand (not his sister's). The first chapter is about the birth of Christ and the three Magi coming to worship the infant Jesus. The Quintus Arrius part is as written - the person who made the comment about a homosexual relationship is obviously not a well read person. Messala did not die after the chariot race but was crippled - a fitting punishment for his awful deeds. Balthazar's daughter Iras becomes involved with Messala and inveigles Judah Ben Hur into a rendezvous where he was to be set upon and killed by Messala's thugs but it did not work. Miriam and Tirzah are trying to get to Jesus and His shadow passes over them and they are cured. Ben Hur finds himself in the Garden of Gethsemene on the night Jesus was arrested and in the Bible it says there was a "young man" there and when the Romans caught hold of his robe he fled naked. The book says this young man was Ben Hur.Although I did enjoy the film I found it disappointing that the main thread of the story was altered so that Judah Ben Hur is a man when he is sent to the galleys and other little things which detract from the message of the book which is subtitled "A Tale of The Christ"

Review title: They just don't make movies like this any more
Review_body: This was a great movie when it first came out, and I still enjoy watching this movie (I purchased the VHS a long time ago). The entire story has everything a person could want, and to realize that a friendship could be destroyed by greed, power, and a sense of entitlement just reflects reality to the nth degree. The story of love of family and love of country is just part of the overall appeal of this movie. In addition, saving the Roman fleet commander ins spite of his hatred of the Romans, indicated a noble spirit beyond mere mortals. This movie is watchable any time, and I just wish they still made movies like this one.

Within 20 minutes of pressing the play button on Ben-Hur, my eyes were locked on the screen. I sat and admired the spectacular sets as they danced across the screen, the unopened mail forgotten in my lap. The sights and sounds of a world 2,000 years gone by appeared to be as real as anything filmed in the present.  From the opening act to the surprising and stunning chariot race at the climax, it was as if I were reading a book that I simply could not put down! The characters were extremely well-developed, and their interactions were intensely emotional. These are people you care about, and you are drawn into their world. I highly recommend this "fiction based on fact" movie.

GENERAL: The friendship between two men degenerating into hate because of their ideals.POSITIVE ASPECTS: The intensity of human issues present in the film.NEGATIVE ASPECTS : Overlong passages in the second part of the film.AVENUES OF REFLECTION: The desire to live of Ben Hur will open the door to multiple interpretations. Everyone can go of his personal vision. But it remains clear that it is his meeting with Christ that will solidify this desire to live, because both have this as the first value. Relations between Ben Hur and Messala are so intense that they approach the extreme love-hate. As the film progresses, the love scenes decline to reach a hate climax at the scene after the victory of Ben Hur in the tent of Messala. With all its torments, Ben Hur is still looking for a meaning to life. He wants to live, but why he wants to live? Ben Hur is imbued with traditional values of the biblical Jewish culture, but his understanding of Christ's sacrifice will make him more accepting forgiveness and new values of Christianity. He will try to make a synthesis with both believing in the respect for life.Hatred allows Ben Hur to survive and Quintus Arrius will make him remark. Some believe that two elements that will allow Ben Hur to survive occur when Christ gives him water to drink and when Quintus Arrius delivers him from his chains. In reality, the image of Christ who gives water to drink refers to reinforce the value of life in Ben Hur. And with regard to the chains, we realize that if it was not at that time, he would have been released at another time, because with his desire to live, he was closely watching every opportunity. We note that Quintus Arrius is attracted to Ben Hur. One suspects that he has sadomasochistic tendencies with convicts. The first time we see him on screen, he go down to see convicts and whip Ben Hur. We often placed hatred as negative, but we realize that intense hatred can also be a driver. We see all the evil inside him. We also remember the love between the two main characters when they meet in the districts of Messala early in the film. Ben Hur reached what Messala valued as a social position, but it was not what Ben Hur sought. In order of importance, the hatred towards Messala and the welfare of his mother and sister, his people and his wife were more important to him. Ben Hur is always thirsty. We try to make us believe that he is no longer thirsty because he heard Christ.

Review title: Still a wonderful movie – especially for my generation.
Review_body: A few nights ago, while working in my home office, I was pulled from my concentration to run out and see what my husband was watching on the TV in the family room. My husband had switched the channel and landed on the slave galley scene from Ben-Hur. The sounds of the drum beating as slaves rowed, was instantly recognizable. I immediately told my husband to press "record" on our DVR to capture the remainder of this epic show. From that moment, I was unable to tear myself away and proceeded to watch the story unfold as the rest of my household went to bed. I sat rapt and weeping yet again over this glorious movie. I remember watching this movie in a movie theater in 1959 with my family when it first came out. I was 3 or 4 years old. I recall that during the extremely intense chariot race I had to cover my eyes and asked my mother to tell me when the scene was over and to tell me "if the good guys won"! That scene, so intense for me then, still caused me to exclaim in trepidation, even now at age 54. Thinking back, I have identified with this movie each of the three times I have watched it. As a child then, my thoughts were about the cruelty of some, the integrity of others and the wonders of this Christ they spoke about. I remember thinking that I hoped I would grow up and have a brother so heroic that he would come and save me like Juda Ben-Hur did when he came back for his sister and mother and carried them out of the Lepers' colony, and also that there would still be men like Christ for my generation. Later on, in my early twenties, I watched this movie again. I remember wishing then that I could meet a man so honorable and heroic (like Juda) who, if in similar circumstances, would come back and save his family and marry me! Now as an adult and mother to a son and daughter, I wept yet again during my viewing (!) and wondered if my family was in similar circumstances, might my son be so strong and heroic that he could survive such cruelties and still feel such love and devotion that he would be able to come back to save his mother and his younger sister? How the years pass. The movie was and still is fantastic and deserves all the accolades it has received.
I seen this movie, very realistic with nice story. Really i like this , actually this is my first review in imdb.

Ben-Hur is one of the greatest biblical tale ever made in Hollywood. Ben-Hur proved to be an intelligent, exciting, and dramatic piece of film-making unlike so many other vulgar Biblical pageants with Hollywood actors and actresses. It was also one of the most honored, award-winning films of all time. It was nominated for twelve Academy Awards, Best Picture, Best Actor (Charlton Heston - his sole career Oscar), Best Supporting Actor (Hugh Griffith), Best Director (William Wyler), Best Color Cinematography, Best Color Art Direction/Set Decoration, Best Sound, Best Score, Best Film Editing, Best Color Costume Design, Best Special Effects, and Best Screenplay. It was the first film to win eleven Oscars and Ben-hur highly deserved it. I highly recommended it.

When I saw this film at the age of fifteen it flew over my head. It was just a little to much to take in. When people would ask me about it I would simply tell them it was one of the classics. Now that my mind can digest the majesty of this film I'm here to tell you that it is a tremendous achievement in film regardless of its age. The movie starts out with the accomplished Roman military leader Messallah returning to Judeah to stamp down Roman law upon the land. We find out soon that he lived in Judeah as a child and was friends with one Judah Ben-Hur who is an aristocrat that has great hope and pride in the future of his people. When the two reunite they see the difference in their views and things quickly fall to pieces. Thats all i will give for the plot. It is a complex and lengthy journey that is both thought provoking and magnificent to behold. Keep in mind when you watch the chariot race that all the footage was shot on the set. This was before visual effects could be effectively applied to add to the realism of big action scenes like this. The score is perhaps the best facet of the film still standing as one of the most celebrated scores of all time. In my top five this is at the top of the list. Don't let the length scare you away. Breath it in and you won't be disappointed.

Review title: Jesus! What a great film destroyed by the last 30 minutes
Review_body: The first 3 hours are definitely stunning.Ben-Hur is a great epic with stunning 70mm cinematography and the story was top-level until, you guessed it - Jesus f'n Christ. I saw it a mile away that Jesus will cure Miryam and Tirza's leprosy which is ridiculous in itself, but the way in which it happened in the end was even more cheesy than expected. He didn't even touch them, they were just passers-by. If Jesus cured people's diseases just by dying wouldn't all diseases be eradicated right there on the spot?And why didn't they show Jesus' face, is he Mohammed or something? Jeezus!

Review title: One of the best movies ever made
Review_body: Such classics as Ben Hur, Spartacus and Quo Vadis are in a league of their own and cannot be in any way compared to modern movies such as Gladiator and Troy. Ben Hur is a deep movie and represents the human spirit and hope to overcome adversity. It is a movie about love conquering hate and betrayal. Its religious undertones are convincing and even the atheist such as myself can identify with the message of the value of human decency, understanding and love for others. It is very much a movie about being brave and doing what is right. If you had to send a spaceship to another galaxy and send our legacy out into space, then I would choose to place this movie on board the probe, and perhaps the story of Spartacus. Perhaps I would include a humorous movie and the Star Wars movies also to make the cargo complete and tell others who we were.

I can't think of a movie that brings the reality of Rome nor the presence of Christ and the two contrasting worlds home more clearly, as well as being a struggle of one man and his soul and a story of life and others in one movie. 10 classic....Profoundly moving as a child when i first saw it ..up their with Star Wars and other for me as a an early influence classic. Real emotions, real character/s and just a great film.....Heston's manly character and inner struggle is supreme and is the back drop and flow of the the film..One of my favourite films on the quiet and a timeless masterpiece. Sit down and watch it one quiet evening.... It IS a great film.

Review title: I would give it 11 of 10 if I could...
Review_body: One of the best movies ever. There are some unforgettable incredible epic scenes in there - just to mention the chariot race or the naval battle - the conflict between the Romans and Judah is very well told. The storyline and Juda's voyage as a roman slave is extraordinary and leaves the viewer wondering that this world simply is "a lot more than what it seems to be". It all tops in the crucification of Jesus Christ.There is a dignity in this movie that I consider to be outstanding. Totally worthy of every Oscar it received. Additionally with Charlton Heston they did make an excellent choice - I think the acting is more than brilliant.From me 11 of 10 stars overall, absolutely excellent. There is a lot more to add to it but this is only going to be a short review so it's just a summary of the basics.

Review title: Lost count of how many times I saw this great film!
Review_body: But I will talk about the time I saw it at the Uptown Theater in Washington DC where it was revived in, I believe, the early 90s. I was amazed at how the audience reacted in the same manner as when I first saw it in 1959 in its Boston opening. They laughed in the same places, oo'd and aw'd in the same places and got thoroughly immersed in that sensational chariot race !!! A patron, upon leaving the theater, said it best -- dated but good ...

First 2 hours - 8/10
Third hour - 9/10
Final hour - 3/10The final hour (following the race) plodded along so painfully that a film on track for a 9/10 only an hour before was turning into a 6 or perhaps even a 5.It settles around a 7 for its visual superlatives and mostly good direction, but is far from perfect and leaves a startingly negative taste with its final hour.

I consider "Ben Hur" an inspirational picture. Many of us are like Judah, in that we are so burned up with hate because of the injustice of the world. We feel lost and cry out to God during personal unfortunate events, and feel Him with us. The best scene in the film is when marched to the galleys, Judah cries out, "God, help me!", and our Lord gives him water. That does it for me! I have this movie on DVD, along with "King Of Kings", "The Robe" and "Jesus Christ Superstar", all of which I consider among the best Biblical movies ever made! The movie itself is basically historically and Biblically correct (even though it is a piece of fiction). However, there are a few inaccuracies here and there, which by no means take away from the grandeur of the film. First of all, the Romans had no concept of "emperor" as the word is understood today. The Roman "emperors" were imperial dictators with a variety of powers (based upon Latin words), which were bestowed upon them by the Senate. They have been labeled "emperors" because one of the titles the Senate gave was "imperator", which in Latin means, "commander-in-chief". The other inaccuracy is the very nature of Tiberius. He was far from the benevolent figure portrayed in this movie, or in "The Robe". Tiberius was a paranoid tyrant, who had members of his family murdered on suspicion of treason. As this film wrongly portrays, he was also never in Rome, but had a private villa on the island of Capri, and left most of the affairs of state to his Praetorian Prefect, Sejanus. Always suspicious, Tiberius opened what he called "treason trials" where rumored enemies of the state were tried, convicted and murdered in cruel and unusual manners.That aside, this film deserves 4 out of 5 stars in my book!

I find it somewhat difficult to describe why "BEN HUR" is indeed my favorite movie of all (I bought a good used two-volume set, and my son bought me the first DVD I ever owned: "BEN HUR"). Maybe it's because there are a number of reasons, some of which I probably can't think of at this time.  When I see "BEN HUR" again - have already seen it more than once, I hope to write down the various reasons why I consider it such a MAGNIFICENT movie.  Some of the reasons are: the TREMENDOUS ACTING; the INCREDIBLE CHARIOT RACE, especially for that time (1959); the BEAUTIFUL COLOR; the movie leaving me FEELING TERRIFIC, not sad, not depressed; the FANTASTIC STORY! My being a Christian makes this movie so very meaningful to me.  For me, two of the GREATEST SCENES (among so very many) are where Jesus gives Ben Hur a drink of water, and the other - ABSOLUTELY THRILLING - is where Ben Hur gives Jesus a drink of water (someone commented on this web site about that scene causing them to have goose bumps)!!!  It is great to know that scene affected someone else so deeply (and probably many, many others as well)!  At this time I can't imagine there ever being a movie that would replace "BEN HUR" as my favorite movie of all time!!!

I have seen this piece of work many times over the years, and each time it seems, I have come away with something more. This is Heston at his best, and he brings out the best in the supporting cast. The scene where Ben Hur is offered a drink of water from Christ after coming out of the desert is as powerful as any I have watched in any movie, and using an angle that never show's the face of Christ seems to make it more remarkable. The movie is so well acted and crafted that the lack of special effects technology available at the time only makes this effort more amazing. What elevates this movie is the story told around the time of the Crucifixion, and interpreting that event into the storyline so as not to be preachy, yet the message is clear. Well worth the time to see it again.

My picks might be; Christian Bale, Matt Bomer, Christian Cooke, Devon Sawa or Peter Facinelli for the lead role of Judah Ben-Hur.For the role of Quintus Arrius, Ben-Hur's rival, my picks might be; Ryan Gosling, Jonathan Rhys Meyers, Sean Faris or Dave Annable.And for the role of Esther, my picks might be; Mila Kunis, Megan Fox, Lily James, Gal Gadot or Monica Raymund.If you love the classics and stories set in ancient Rome, this is a must see!!!

Review title: Current Formats Diminish The Film's Original Majestic Impact
Review_body: In their determination to make the most spectacular movie ever made, and the blockbuster to top all previous blockbusters, MGM and company unintentionally created a work of popular art that could only be fully appreciated in its original, pristine print, 70mm, super widescreen glory. These are the screenings moviegoers who love this film remember. The astonishing depth of field. The saturated richness of the color. The almost demented attention to detail. The overpowering use of sound and motion, especially in the chariot race. Viewed in its original format, "Ben-Hur" was rightly hailed a masterpiece. The vast majority of moviegoers left theatres spellbound and drained. Unfortunately, all this shock and awe is diminished when experienced via faded prints in revival theatres or the miniaturizing trivialization of video or DVD. On TV, we might as well be watching ants; hence, in all but the most extreme closeups, the emotional connection with the actors is lost. Furthermore, contemporary audiences tend to find the quasi-Shakespearean acting stodgy and old-fashioned. Charlton Heston, the lead, has been especially lambasted of late for either woodenness or overacting (though how he can exemplify both is beyond be). Younger viewers should remember that he and the rest of the cast have stage backgrounds, where deep, resonant voices, trick accents, and clear diction are the standard. Considered in this light, the acting's great. Finally, the late '50s was not a time for Slouching-Towards-Gomorrah hipness. Still, the 1959 "Ben-Hur" was as contemporary a treatment of the antique novel as one could hope for. It carefully negotiates potentially explosive theological minefields with greater respect and aplomb than Mel Gibson's recent and controversial "The Passion." And its literate script is astonishingly timeless in delineating the power struggles of Middle Eastern identity politics--"These people are drunk with religion." "How do you fight an idea?" "With another idea." Sounds like CNN or Fox News to me. There continues to be much to appreciate in this venerable classic, if people will give it a (four-hour) chance, and allow their mind's eye to imagine it as it once was, in 1959, on the big screen.

Review title: The Greatest Movie I've Ever Seen!
Review_body: I've seen a few of Charlton Heston's films before. And as a Catholic, I think most of his movies are superb. But this is by far the greatest of all of his films! Ben Hur, is absolutely the greatest movie I've ever seen! The story of Judah Ben Hur, and the life of Christ is absolutely moving. This is one of the only movies that have made me cry. Not tears of Sadness, but of joy. Judah's run in with Jesus left me almost trembling. As corny as it sounds, this movie really moved me. I think that there is no doubt that this is Charlton Heston's greatest role! Aside from the run ins with Jesus, there is the widely known chariot race that left me on edge, and the sea battle scene, where Ben Hur is enslaved on a ship, along with about a hundred other slaves rowing it along the sea. Although the movie is tied with LORD OF THE RINGS, and TITANIC for most Acadamy Awards won on a movie, I think this is by far the greatest of the three.

I have seen Ben-Hur (I also like the 1925 version very much) I don't know how many times now. I think I have stopped counting seven years ago. I never tire to see this movie and, needless to say, I know all the scenes and dialogue by heart. This picture has everything in it. Almost all human sentiments are represented in the story: joy, sorrow, despair, pride, jealousy, hope, revenge, anger, forgiveness, compassion, redemption, love, hate, friendship, humour, etc, etc. During the three and a half hours it takes for the story to unfold, we see passing by our very eyes just about every example of what constitutes the human condition. What I find even more remarkable in this movie is the fact that Christ is present throughout the entire story, but we don't really see him in the flesh (at the exception of a few scenes, where the Lord is, in fact, in the background) and yet, his spirit and message is ever present through the words and actions of the various characters. It's not for nothing that the complete title of this great story is "Ben-Hur, a Tale of the Christ". The movie is well-acted (especially Heston, Griffith, Hawkins and, let's not forget, the wonderful Finley Currie, playing Balthazar), the dialogue is always concise, yet never short of meaning and substance (the way dialogues in movies should be), the decor and settings are just magnificent and the Miklos Rozsa score is simply superb. Besides Quo Vadis (the 1951 version, which, incidentally, I have recommended to those who have also enjoyed Ben-Hur), I cannot think of a better movie about the early days of Christianity than this one. There are others, of course, (The Robe, just to name one), but none has the grandeur and the spectacular dimension of Ben-Hur. It's the movie I would want to watch one last time on my death bed. I gladly and proudly give Ben-Hur a score of 10 out of 10!

I don't get why this is such a highly esteemed film. It's not even one of Charlton Heston's best films. It's 3.5 hours with almost no interesting dialog, characters, or plot. There's 1 good scene in the entire movie, the chariot race. Anti-climactic ending. I'm guessing it's just enjoyed by Christians who love anything with a Christian theme in it.There are far better movies for every facet of this movie. If you want a good Charlton Heston film -> Planet of the Apes If you want a good Roman-era action movie -> Gladiator If you want a good revenge story -> The Count of Monte Cristo If you want a story line adjacent to Jesus' -> The Life of Brian

Ben-Hur defines the term "epic". Story, characters, script, screen play, production values all focused on creating a truly memorable work of art. A movie I never get tired of watching, a fantastic piece of entertainment. Evokes the sort of emotion that only those really special movies can. Certainly the best movie of the "historical epic" genre, but transcends any category to stand out as one of the greatest movies ever made. The people who saw this on its original release must have been awe struck and amazed. I'm still searching for a movie that can get the same response from people, regardless of age, gender, creed or colour. Just an amazing example of how good you can make something, if you really care about the end product.

Review title: Ben Hur is a epic film full of emotion and lessons that won any academic prizes.
Review_body: The movie Ben Hur, released in 1959, is about a young courageous man devoted to his faith and freedom of Jewish. He is falsely accused by his friend and made into slave, and his family is put into prison. After years of slavery, he comes back wealthy and seeks for revenge, and then find out his mother and sister contacted with leprosy while in jail. When he witnesses the Crucifixion, he feels like he is touched by Jesus Christ as all of his hatred vanished. The cast of the movie were talents with very good acting skills. For example, Charlton Heston was a well-known actor that won many prizes for his acting. The movie was well-filmed in general. The scenes are filmed in Brazil and they are big and great so that they leave audience in awe. This movie's audience range is wide, anyone can watch. It also attracts many Jewish and Christian people for the film has some matters involving Christian. Also, the movie is a box office success with the budget of $16,000,000 and the gross of $70,000,000 (only in the U.S.). Also, there are a lot of identical works with the same name produced in 1907, 1925, 2003 and some other TV series and plays. The most dramatic scene is the moment when Ben Hur feels Jesus Christ in his soul that makes him so relieved and free of sorrow and hatred. This scene also touched many audiences by showing them lessons of forgiveness and the presence of Christ in soul. To me, any 212-minute film is too long, but this masterpiece just makes me could not take my eyes off the screen. It was interesting and full of lessons of courage, love and forgiveness.

Review title: Funny how subtexts change over time ...
Review_body: When the movie was made British actors were chosen to play the Roman occupying forces, and Americans to play the oppressed Jews - considering their roots, that would of course appeal to Americans. But things have changed from a time when Americans would see themselves as "good guys" in the Cold War. Being the one Rome-like superpower, it's the United States' turn to impose an empire's glory upon the world whether those countries with unhealthy climates want it or not. When I watched the movie the other day parallels with the current situation in Iraq were so obvious that I found the movie quite subversive and amusing - not what you would expect from "Ben Hur".

Review_body: One of the best movies ever. Very strong emotions. You re living the movie while you are watching it.

Review title: I wish more movies were like this!
Review_body: As a teen, watching this movie made me wish that other movies today were as good as this one. It had depth which movies today definitely lack. I enjoyed every second of this movie. I cannot wait to watch it again, even though it is rather long. This movie was suspenseful yet romantic. I loved when Messala found out that Ben-Hur was alive. And the chariot race was even better. I would sometime in my life, would like to read the novel and see if it is just as good as the movie. It was so funny seeing how they did the war scenes then and looking at war scenes now. And how the technology has changed so much. This movie had it's sad parts just like any other movie, with the Crucifixion, and Ben-Hur's family being lepers. But in the end it all turns out well, at least for his families sake. This movie had a great cast including Charleton Heston, one of the most renowned actors of his time. WE NEED MORE MOVIES LIKE THIS ONE!!

I have watched this movie at least a dozen times and still get goosebumps watching it. To me, it is by far the greatest cinematic event to appear on screen. If you have never seen Ben-Hur, by all means check it out, and the DVD version with the updated sound system and letterbox format is well worth it. True, the distant shots of the ships don't exactly meet today's criteria, but the sea battle is superb, and the chariot race surpasses a lot of action in our epic movies today. This is one of those movies where all the elements come together...the script, acting, cinematography, and best of all, the music score, composed by Miklos Rozsa! I still on occasion hear high-school bands perform the "Parade of the Charioteers" musical section from the movie. If you enjoyed "Gladiator," you'll love Ben-Hur. It would be a mortal sin if MGM even thought of doing a remake. The original couldn't get any better.

I read many comments about 'Jesus Christ' in Ben-Hur like 'The few moments which have Christ on the screen are still moving' 'Jesus is always shown from behind and never speaks, but we know it's Him by the long-blow-dried brown hair and the white robe'... I have decided to give it a small bit of recognition to the mysterious actor who played the 'big' part of Jesus Christ...uncredited on the screen, his name is Claude Heater...an American opera singer...still alive and living in San Francisco !...the only film he made. After a very long research (years and years)I got Claude Heater on the phone (from Belgium)...after a long 'interview'(difficult because I speak french)...we still very close, and he sent to me two color stills from 'Jesus' from the front, amazing face,just like a traditional Jesus. Then during my trip to California...I met him personally, a tall man with a strong personality. It's was a very choice from William Wyler, Do you want to know more about Claude Heater ?...
